{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3329210,"name":"","username":"MoonlitJolty","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/moonlitjolty/{size}/12129_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-10T18:41:53.834Z","cooked":"

We’re currently running into an issue where our code will crash due to an out of memory error after anywhere between 1.5 - 120 minutes. Following the suggestions I’ve found via CD and WPILib docs, I set up the jvmargs to connect with VisualVM and debug what’s using up the memory. Unfortunately, upon attempting to connect it simply crashes the code instead. The most recent crashlog can be found here. I’m not sure where to even begin in debugging these issues

The WPILib docs have been recently updated to include steps on how to deal with OOM issues. Try these in order and you should be able to resolve it.

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Java Garbage Collection

Java garbage collection is the process of automatically managing memory for Java objects. The Java Virtual Machine (JVM) is responsible for creating and destroying objects, and the garbage collecto...

I did follow the steps and implemented the fixes as I could. The code hasn’t crashed since, but that’s only been with it on for about 10 or so minutes which easily falls within the sporadic range we had before so I don’t know if it has helped or not. The big concern is the fact that VisualVM crashes the code, and as such I can’t actually see the memory usage to debug it any further than just hope those steps worked.

You can run visualvm in simulation without reverting the gradle changes. The robot program will just show up as a process on your local computer.

Having been running the robot with the sysctl flags set from the troubleshooting guide and manual garbage collection calls every 10 or so seconds we’ve yet to see another crash. We were also able to get visualvm to work correctly when swap was set up on a USB drive, so we appear to be all good now. Thanks for the recommended troubleshooting steps, and we’ll be looking to see what exactly is eating up all the memory when we have the time to do so.
